children.subject: I think s/he just means open-source projects.

Just a warning though is that open-source projects are hard to contribute to. There is a open secret in the open source world that a lot of the successful open source projects are actually written by full time salaried software engineers paid to write it.

However, using open source software is definitely a good way to get experience.
You could get involved in a github repo that interests you! It's a great way to gain hands on experience

Whatever you decide to do in trying to gain practical experience, be sure to keep practicing your data structures and algorithms. This is one of the primary metrics companies use to gauge your ability. Use sites like LeetCode and Hackerrank.

history.content: There are several free courses on Edx.org that might be helpful for picking up language syntax that often bogs students down.  We really recommend coming into 61A with some python knowledge as the course takes off pretty quickly.

I'm a transfer which means I don't have time to go through the motions before I start trying to find work/internships. I'm currently enrolled in cs61a, and while I'm doing good in the class I really don't feel like it's teaching me how to build useful software. My goal is to secure a paid internship this summer and even though I always hear that 61b is a good class to do that, I want to get started learning on getting skills someone would pay for ASAP.

Are there any good resources, groups, etc. that can help students who can to gain CS/coding experience outside of classes on campus? I know there's clubs like codebase, but given that they're so hard to get in it's hard to bank on them as being helpful options. I'd love to learn from some people and potentially shadow/"intern" with people working on industry code to gain skills with some mentorship. 

If anyone knows what to do or has good ideas, I'd love to know!
history.subject: How to gain practical programming skills/experience?
